A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.
Given a subset \(U \subset \bar{K}^{n}\), the corresponding ideal \(I(U)\) in the polynomial ring \(K[X]\) consists of all polynomials that vanish on \(U\).
Does the concept of a/an Noetherian ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Ideal corresponding to a subset to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of an Ideal corresponding to a subset, as defined, involves identifying all polynomials in a polynomial ring that vanish on a given subset. This definition is independent of the properties of the ring itself, such as whether it is Noetherian or not. The definition of an Ideal corresponding to a subset does not require any conditions on the ring's structure regarding ascending chains of ideals or the finite generation of ideals.\n\nOn the other hand, the concept of a Noetherian ring pertains to the behavior of chains of ideals within the ring and whether every ideal is finitely generated. This property of a ring being Noetherian is significant in many areas of algebra, but it is not a prerequisite for the definition or understanding of an Ideal corresponding to a subset. The definition of the Ideal corresponding to a subset can be applied to any polynomial ring, regardless of whether it is Noetherian or not.
